concepts.description: AI4EO Ecosystem Analysis
concepts.name: AI4EO Ecosystem Analysis

concepts.description: There are a vast range of data that may be potentially of use. Given the aim of combining the use of AI and EO, we will consider data providers as being providers of either (a) EO or (b) other data for training or validation.
concepts.name: Data providers

concepts.description: Novel options for accessing and processing the EO data. A growing array of online EO hubs and platforms, both commercial and research focused, are emerging in response to new user requirements stimulated by this trend. These cloud platforms provide combined EO data search and generic research capabilities, often with specific tools to develop new processing workflows and scale them up to support large scale batch or scheduled processing.
concepts.name: Processing Platforms

concepts.description: A wide range of software tools for AI and ML applications of EO data. Many satellite data applications can achieve their aims effectively with simple software with no AI specialisation at all. As this resource addresses the intersection of AI and EO, we will consider software that addresses AI or ML methods in a specific way.
concepts.name: Software Tools

concepts.description: This category includes commercial companies and public sector organisations who are currently developing or delivering services based on information extraction from EO data using AI methods. In several cases, EO companies   have established new EO analytics platforms using AI to extract information and insights from backend EO data archives.
concepts.name: Service Providers

concepts.description: There is a growing and active research community concerned with the combined use of AI methods and EO data. These funded projects span development of new methods and technologies, plus efforts to build capacity and the community.
concepts.name: Researchers and Research Funding

concepts.description: Related to the growing application of AI and EO, numerous training and learning resources are available.
concepts.name: Training and Learning Resources

concepts.description: The last, but perhaps the most important group are the end users who want actionable insight from the data. Ultimately this sector are the consumers who value the information being provided to them and who drive the requirements for information and services. The range of uses are growing and almost as broad as the entire EO user base. Providing a detailed breakdown is beyond the scope of this resource and more comprehensively addressed in EO market analyses such as those compiled by Euroconsult  and EARSC. But it is clear AI and EO will combine to provide key information across public and private sectors, input to scientific research programmes and NGOs, plus policy advice and monitoring of targets such as UN Sustainable Development Goals.
concepts.name: End Users

concepts.description: Satellites are used to forecast the weather, answer important Earth-science questions, provide essential information to improve agricultural practices, maritime safety, help when disaster strikes, and all manner of everyday applications. The need for these data is increasing resulting in the diversity and volume of data delivered by EO satellites increasing significantly in recent years.
concepts.name: EO Data

concepts.description: With respect to ML method development, the lack of suitable training data is a frequently encountered problem. Labelled data is scarce.  The application of ML to EO data can only be realised with high-quality training data which encompasses all the features that we aim to identify, map, and monitor. A diverse and functional AI4EO ecosystem will need to include open training data libraries providing a repository for registering labelled data so that it can be discovered and shared openly. However, there is a reluctance to share such data due to a combination of technical, financial, competitive and policy constraints.
concepts.name: Training and Validation Data

concepts.description: For the purpose of allowing data, infrastructure, tool, algorithm and knowledge owners to share their assets, allowing users to easily get access to satellite data and extract information out of them without the need to download any dataset. This availability of all the needed ingredients in a shared collaboration environment represents a unique opportunity for science and applications but also poses a major challenge in realizing its full potential in terms of data exploitation.
concepts.name: Thematic Exploitation Platforms

concepts.description: openEO develops an open API that connects clients like R, Python and JavaScript to big EO cloud back-ends in a simple and unified way.
concepts.name: openEO

concepts.description: Numerous examples of established remote sensing and EO image processing desktop software tools have added specific AI and ML tools (supervised/unsupervised classification, target identification, change detection) to support automated extraction of information.
concepts.name: Desktop

concepts.description: Increasingly tools such as R and Python are being used to analyse EO data. A number of open-source packages now exist which act as a bridge between EO data and established python tools for data science and machine learning.
concepts.name: Open Source

concepts.description: EO companies   have established new EO analytics platforms using AI to extract information and insights from backend EO data archives.
concepts.name: Analystics Platforms

concepts.description: Providers currently using AI in the Earth Observation service market.
concepts.name: Service Market

concepts.description: The European Commision Horizon 2020 Space programme and related funding initiatives support several very large research projects on big data and artificial intelligence for Copernicus and Earth Observation.
concepts.name: Copernicus

concepts.description: Beyond these large EC projects are numerous other R&D activities in the private, academic, government and NGO sectors, spanning all topics where EO data is a data input. The most accessible route to a comprehensive view of ‘who is doing what’ can be obtained by looking at the programs of numerous AI for EO conferences and conference sessions in recent years.
concepts.name: Wider Research and Development Activities

concepts.description: The rapidly growing area of digital twins for the environment are set to drive the combined use of EO and AI methods in the coming years and decades.
concepts.name: Digital Twins

concepts.description: Several research networks and groups are emerging which aim to focus on topics related to AI and EO. These groups broadly aim to coordinate and maintain longer-term activities focused on new methods or wider adoption of these methods.
concepts.name: Research networks

concepts.description: Forest health mapping, forest fire monitoring.
concepts.name: Forestry

concepts.description: Border surveillance, vessel detection and identification.
concepts.name: Security

concepts.description: Air quality information, pollution tracking and forecasting.
concepts.name: Air Quality

concepts.description: Ocean current and sea state monitoring, marine protected Areas monitoring.
concepts.name: Maritime

concepts.description: Oilfield monitoring, pipeline monitoring.
concepts.name: Oil and Gas

concepts.description: Site assessment and selection, energy supply forecasts.
concepts.name: Renewable Energy

concepts.description: Assessment of risk exposure, hazard forecast and early warning.
concepts.name: Natural Disasters

concepts.description: Urban infrastructure monitoring, urban heat monitoring.
concepts.name: Urban Monitoring

concepts.description: Conservation adn biodivesrity knowledge.
concepts.name: Wildlife Monitoring

concepts.description: Formal qualifications at undergraduate, postgraduate and doctoral level.
concepts.name: Formal Qulaifications

concepts.description: Building skills with courses, certificates, and degrees online from world-class universities and companies.
concepts.name: Coursera

concepts.description: Algorithms performing tasks without explicitly programmed to do so. The performance improves through experience during the training phase.
concepts.name: Machine Learning

concepts.description: Grouping unlabelled data such that objects within a group are in some sense similar.
concepts.name: Clustering

concepts.description: From data with class labels the algorithm learns to which class an unseen data point belongs.
concepts.name: Classification

concepts.description: From trainign data the algorithm learns a mapping from input to output and is then used to predict the output for unseen input.
concepts.name: Regression

concepts.description: Data is transformed from a highdimensional feature space to a low dimensional one while retaining the relevant information.
concepts.name: Dimensionality Reduction

concepts.description: In a neural network linear and non-linear transformations are applied to the input data and in subsequent layers. The output layer gives a result. The type of transformations depends on the network architecture. Learning is via the minimisation of a suitable loss function.
concepts.name: Deep Learning

concepts.description: The underlying assumption is that the data are generated by a given number of processes each with its own probability distribution. The task is to infer these distributions and the mixing probabilities.
concepts.name: Mixture Models

concepts.description: The underlying assumption is that the data are generated by a unknown number of processes each with its own probability distribution. The task is to infer the number of processes, their distributions and the mixing probabilities.
concepts.name: Infinite Processes

contributors.description: Collaboration between Φ-Lab of the European Space Agency (ESA) and the UKRI Centre for Doctoral Training (CDT) in the Application of Artificial Intelligence to the study of Environmental Risks (AI4ER), hosted jointly by University of Cambridge and British Antarctic Survey. It facilitates high impact innovative research sprints. To select end-user relevant topics,  AI4ER partners who come from industry, the third sector as well as national and international institutions, help setting several environmental themes. Themes are focussed into specific challenge questions which are tackled by the AI4ER master students in two teams from December to March.
contributors.name: AI4EO Accelerator
Norway’s International Climate & Forests Initiative and Planet Labs

contributors.description: Copernicus Access Platform Intermediate Layers Small Scale Demonstrator
contributors.name: CANDELA
Vlaamse Instelling Voor Technologisch Onderzoek N.V.
Earth Observation Data Centre for Water Resources Monitoring GmbH
Sinergise Laboratorij Za Geografske Informacijske Sisteme Doo
Joint Research Centre of the European Commission
Airbus Defence and Space – One Atlas
UP42 – Open marketplace and EO analytics platform

contributors.name: Ubotica

contributors.description: Fusing multi-resolution and multi-sensor earth observation data with ML and AI to provide near-real time actionable geospatial insights.
contributors.name: Earthi

contributors.description: Using machine learning for real-time detection of Earth science phenomena.
contributors.name: Phenomena Detection Portal

contributors.description: Utilises satellite technology to provide an irrefutable means of reporting forestry changes and verifying sustainable sourcing.
contributors.name: Starling

contributors.description: A digital twin platform that uses AI and cloud computing to automatically transform input such as satellite data, aerial images or map and sensor data into building and landscape assets that contribute to a photorealistic 3D environment.
contributors.name: Blackshark.ai

contributors.description: Use artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques to improve the accuracy of derived products.
contributors.name: EarthWave

contributors.description: Copernicus Artificial Intelligence Services and data fusion with other distributed data sources and processing at the edge to support DIAS and HPC infrastructures.

contributors.description: Global Earth Monitor.

contributors.description: A common, open source interface between Earth Observation data infrastructures and front-end applications.
contributors.name: OpenEO

contributors.description: Explainable AI Pipelines for Big Copernicus Data.
contributors.name: DeepCube

contributors.description: Big Data knowledge extraction and re-creation platform.
contributors.name: PerceptiveSentinel

contributors.description: Big-data Earth Observation Technology and Tools Enhancing Research and development.
contributors.name: BETTER

contributors.description: Advancing the State-of-the-Art for Rapid and Continuous Land Monitoring.
contributors.name: RapidAI4EO

contributors.name: Extreme Earth
The 1st Artificial Intelligence for Copernicus Workshop

contributors.name: Phi Week 2020
Workshop on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence for Earth Observation

contributors.description: Initiative established by the EC aims to develop a very high precision digital model of the Earth to monitor and simulate natural and human activity.
contributors.name: Destination Earth (DestinE)

contributors.description: Includes targeted activities on forests, food system, climate, hydrology, oceans and Antarctica.
contributors.name: ESA Digital Twin Earth Precursor

contributors.description: Strives to bring the worlds of AI and EO closer together to kindle and encourage interaction and collaboration.
contributors.name: AI4EO)

contributors.description: What role can data science & AI play in addressing the challenges associated with environmental change?
contributors.name: Turing Environment & Sustainability interest group

contributors.description: The Φ-lab’s mission is to accelerate the future of earth observation, by helping Europe’s earth observation and space researchers and companies adopt disruptive technologies and methods.
contributors.name: ESA Φ-lab

contributors.description: Machine Learning for Earth And Climate Sciences.
contributors.name: ELLIS

contributors.description: Artificial Intelligence for Earth Observation – Reasoning, Uncertainties, Ethics and Beyond.
contributors.name: Future Lab AI4EO

contributors.description: United Nations Environment Programme World Conservation Monitoring Centre
contributors.name: UNEP-WCMC

contributors.description: World Wildlife Fund
contributors.name: WWF

contributors.description: Centre for Doctoral Training in Artificial Intelligence for the study of Environmental Risks.
contributors.name: AI4ER

contributors.description: Broad introduction to machine learning, datamining, and statistical pattern recognition.
contributors.name: Machine Learning

contributors.description: Foundational program to understand the capabilities, challenges, and consequences of deep learning. Building and training neural network architectures such as Convolutional Neural Networks, Recurrent Neural Networks, LSTMs, Transformers. Strategies such as Dropout, BatchNorm, Xavier/He initialization, and more.
contributors.name: Deeep Learning

contributors.description: Fundamental nature of remote sensing and the platforms and sensor types used. In-depth treatment of the computational algorithms employed in image understanding, ranging from the earliest historically important techniques to more recent approaches based on deep learning.
contributors.name: Remote Sensing Image Acquisition, Analysis and Applications

contributors.description: K clusters are formed by iteratively changing the cluster assignments of data points and recalculating the cluster mean. In the end, each data point belongs to the cluster with the nearest mean.
contributors.name: K-Means Clustering

contributors.description: The processes generating the data follow a Gaussian probability distribution.
contributors.name: Gaussian Mixture Models

contributors.description: The Expectation-Maximization algorithm iteratively estimates the parameters of of a mixture of distiributions by alternating between approximating the expectation of the log-liklihood given the current parameters and then maximizing this approximation with regards to the parameters.
contributors.name: Expectation-Maximization

contributors.description: The assumption is that the parameters describing the distributions of the processses generating the data themselves follow distributions. The parameter of these distributions, known as hyperparameters, need to be determined.
contributors.name: Bayesian Mixture Models

contributors.description: In the process generating the data, a new data point can either follow one of the distributions of the data already generated or follow a completely new distribution.
contributors.name: The Chinese Restaurant Process

contributors.description: The Dirichlet Process infers the process which generated the data iteratively. The number of clusters can change up or down. Up, if a new data point does not fit well into any of the current clusters. Down, if all data points of a particular cluster are assigned during the iterations to other clusters and that cluster is empty.
contributors.name: Dirichlet Process
